to the number line,
to your output space,

So back over here,

slide.text:
## What you need to be familiar with before starting this lesson: - [Partial derivatives](g/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives/) - [Vector fields](g/a/vector-fields) - [Contour maps](g/a/contour-maps)—only necessary for one section of this lesson. ## What we're building toward - The gradient of a scalar-valued multivariable function $f(x, y, \dots)$, denoted $
abla f$, packages all its partial derivative information into a vector: > $ 
abla f = \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} \\ \vdots \end{array} ight] $ In particular, this means $
abla f$ is a vector-valued function. - If you imagine standing at a point ($x_0, y_0, \dots$) in the input space of $f$, the vector $
abla f(x_0, y_0, \dots)$ tells you which direction you should travel to increase the value of $f$ most rapidly. - These gradient vectors—$
abla f(x_0, y_0, \dots)$—are also perpendicular to the contour lines of $f$. ## Definition After learning that functions with a multidimensional input have [partial derivatives](g/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives/), you might wonder what the full derivative of such a function is. In the case of **scalar-valued multivariable functions**, meaning those with a multidimensional input but a one-dimensional output, the answer is the gradient. The **gradient** of a function $f$, denoted as $
abla f$, is the collection of all its partial derivatives into a vector. [[☃ image 3]] This is most easily understood with an example. ## Example 1: Two dimensions If $f(x, y) = x^2 - xy$, which of the following represents $
abla f$? > [[☃ graded-group 1]] > [[☃ explanation 2]] Notice, $
abla f$ is a **vector-valued function**, specifically one with a two-dimensional input and a two-dimensional output. This means it can be nicely visualized with a [vector field](g/a/vector-fields). That vector field lives in the input space of $f$, which is the $xy$-plane. This vector field is often called the **gradient field** of $f$. [[☃ image 1]] **Reflection question**: Why are the vectors in this vector field so small along the upward diagonal stripe in the middle of the $xy$-plane? [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ explanation 1]] ## Example 2: Three dimensions What is the gradient of $f(x, y, z) = x - xy + z^2$? > [[☃ graded-group 1]] > [[☃ explanation 1]] $
abla f$ is a function with a three-dimensional input and a three-dimensional output. As such, it is nicely visualized with a vector field in three-dimensional space. [[☃ video 1]] ## Interpreting the gradient In each example above, we pictured $
abla f$ as a vector field, but how do we interpret these vector fields? More concretely, let's think about the case where the input of $f$ is two-dimensional. The gradient turns each input point $(x_0, y_0)$ into the vector $ egin{align} \quad 
abla f(x_0, y_0) = \left[  egin{array}{c} \  rac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0, y_0) \ \  rac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0, y_0) \end{array} ight]. \end{align}$ What does that vector tell us about the behavior of the function around the point $(x_0, y_0)$? [[☃ image 1]] Think of the graph of $f$ as a hilly terrain. If you are standing on the part of the graph directly above—or below—the point $(x_0, y_0)$, the slope of the hill depends on which direction you walk. For example, if you step straight in the positive $x$ direction, the slope is $ rac{\partial f}{\partial x}$; if you step straight in the positive $y$-direction, the slope is $ rac{\partial f}{\partial y}$. But most directions are some combination of the two. [[☃ explanation 1]] > **The most important thing to remember about the gradient**: The gradient of $f$, if evaluated at an input $(x_0, y_0)$, points in the direction of steepest ascent. So, if you walk in the direction of the gradient, you will be going straight up the hill. Similarly, *the magnitude of the vector $
abla f(x_0, y_0)$ tells you what the slope of the hill is* in that direction. It is not immediately clear *why* putting the partial derivatives into a vector gives you the slope of steepest ascent, but this will be explained once we get to [directional derivatives](g/a/directional-derivative-introduction). When the inputs of a function $f$ live in more than two dimensions, we can no longer comfortably picture its graph as hilly terrain. That said, the same underlying idea holds. Whether the input space of $f$ is two-dimensional, three-dimensional, or 1,000,000-dimensional: the gradient of $f$ gives a vector in that input space that points in the direction that makes the function $f$ increase the fastest. ## Example 3: What local maxima look like Consider the function $f(x, y) = -x^4 + 4(x^2 - y^2)-3$. What is its gradient? [[☃ graded-group 1]] [[☃ explanation 1]] Here's what the graph of $f$ looks like: [[☃ image 5]] Notice that it has two peaks. Here's what the vector field for $
abla f$ looks like—vectors colored more red should be understood to be longer, and vectors colored more blue should be understood to be shorter: [[☃ image 7]] The two input points corresponding with the peaks in the graph of $f$ are surrounded by arrows directed towards those points. Why? This is because near the top of a hill, the direction of steepest ascent always points towards the peak. **Reflection question**: What would the gradient field of a function look like near the local minimum of that function? [[☃ explanation 2]] ## The gradient is perpendicular to contour lines Like vector fields, [contour maps](ways-to-represent-multivariable-functions/a/contour-maps) are also drawn on a function's input space, so we might ask what happens if the vector field of $
abla f$ sits on top of the contour map corresponding for $f$. For example, let's take the function $f(x, y) = xy$: [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] Looking at the image above, you might notice something interesting: *Each vector is perpendicular to the contour line it touches.* To see why this is true, take a particular contour line, say the one representing the output two, and zoom in to a point on that line. We know that the gradient $
abla f$ points in the direction which increases the value of $f$ most quickly. There are two ways to think about this direction: 1. Choose a fixed step size, and find the direction such that a step of that size increases $f$ the most. [[☃ image 4]] - Choose a fixed increase in $f$, and find the direction such that it takes the *shortest* step to increase $f$ by that amount. [[☃ image 5]] Either way, you're trying to maximize the rise over run, either by maximizing the rise, or minimizing the run. Contour maps provide a good illustration of what this second perspective might look like. In Figure 2 above, there is a second contour line representing 2.1, which is slightly greater than the value 2 represented by the initial line. The gradient of $f$ should point in the direction that will get to this second line with as short a step as possible. The more we zoom in, the more these lines will look like straight, parallel lines. *The shortest path from one line to another that is parallel to it is always perpendicular to both lines*, so the gradient will look perpendicular to the contour line. ## The del operator In multivariable calculus—and beyond—the word **operator** comes up a lot. This might sound fancy, but for the most part, you can think of operator as meaning "thing which turns a function into another function". The derivative is one example of an operator since it turns a function $f$ into a new function $f'$. **Differential operators** are all operators that extend the idea of a derivative to a different context. **Example differential operators** || || || -|-|- || **Name** | **Symbol** | **Example** || Derivative | $ rac{d}{dx}$ | $ rac{d}{dx}(x^2) = 2x$ || Partial derivative | $ rac{\partial}{\partial x}$ | $ rac{\partial}{\partial x}(x^2-xy) = 2x-y$ || Gradient | $
abla$ | $
abla(x^2 - xy) = \left[ egin{array}{c} 2x - y \ -x \end{array}ight]$ This symbol $
abla$ is referred to either as nabla or del. Typically nabla refers to the symbol itself while del refers to the operator it represents. This can be confusing since del can also refer to the symbol $\partial$, but hey, when has math terminology ever been reasonable? Whatever you want to call it, the operator $
abla$ can be loosely thought of as a vector of partial derivative operators: > $ 
abla = \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \ \quad \ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \ \quad \ \vdots \end{array}ight] $ This isn't quite a real definition. For one thing, the dimension of this vector is not defined since it depends on how many inputs there are in the function $
abla$ is applied to. Furthermore, it's playing things pretty fast and loose to make a vector out of operators. But, because in practice the meaning is usually clear, people rarely worry about it. Imagine "multiplying" this vector by a scalar-valued function: > $ egin{align} 
abla f &= \left[  egin{array}{c}  rac{\partial}{\partial x} \ \quad \  rac{\partial}{\partial y} \ \quad \ \vdots \end{array} ight]f \\ &= \left[  egin{array}{c}  rac{\partial f}{\partial x} \ \quad \  rac{\partial f}{\partial y} \ \quad \ \vdots \end{array} ight] \end{align}$ Of course, this is not multiplication, you are really just evaluating each partial derivative operator on the function. Nevertheless, this is a *super* helpful way to think about $
abla$ since it comes up again in the context of several more operators we will learn about later: [divergence](divergence/a/divergence/), [curl](curl/a/curl-warmup/), and the Laplacian. ## Summary - The gradient of a scalar-valued multivariable function $f(x, y, \dots)$, denoted $
abla f$, packages all its partial derivative information into a vector: > $ 
abla f = \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} \\ \vdots \end{array} ight] $ In particular, this means $
abla f$ is a vector-valued function. - If you imagine standing at a point $(x_0, y_0, \dots)$ in the input space of $f$, the vector $
abla f(x_0, y_0, \dots)$ tells you which direction you should travel to increase the value of $f$ most rapidly. - These gradient vectors $
abla f(x_0, y_0, \dots)$ are also perpendicular to the contour lines of $f$.

## Background: - [Partial derivatives](partial-derivatives/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives/) ## Generalizing the second derivative Consider a function with a two-dimensional input, such as $f(x, y) = x^2 y^3$. Its partial derivatives $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ and $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} $ take in that same two-dimensional input $(x, y)$: $\begin{align} &\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \blueE{x}} = \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}(\blueE{x}^2 y^3) = 2\blueE{x} y^3 \\\\ &\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \redE{y}} = \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}}(x^2 \redE{y}^3) = 3x^2 \redE{y}^2 \end{align}$ Therefore, we could also take the partial derivatives *of the partial derivatives*. These are called **second partial derivatives**, and the notation is analogous to the $\dfrac{d^2 f}{dx^2}$ notation for the ordinary second derivative in single-variable calculus: $\begin{align} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \blueE{x}} \right) &= \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial \blueE{x}^2} \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \redE{y}} \right) &= \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial \blueE{x} \partial \redE{y}} \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \blueE{x}} \right) &= \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial \redE{y} \partial \blueE{x}} \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \redE{y}} \right) &= \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial \redE{y}^2} \end{align}$ Using the $f_x$ notation for the partial derivative (in this case with respect to $x$), you might also see these second partial derivatives written like this: $\begin{align} (f_\blueE{x})_\blueE{x} &= f_{\blueE{x}\blueE{x}} \\\\ (f_\redE{y})_\blueE{x} &= f_{\redE{y}\blueE{x}} \\\\ (f_\blueE{x})_\redE{y} &= f_{\blueE{x}\redE{y}} \\\\ (f_\redE{y})_\redE{y} &= f_{\redE{y}\redE{y}} \end{align}$ The second partial derivatives which involve multiple distinct input variables, such as $f_{\redE{y}\blueE{x}}$ and $ f_{\blueE{x}\redE{y}}$, are called "**mixed partial derivatives**" ## Example 1: The full tree **Problem**: Find all the second partial derivatives of $f(x, y) = \sin(x)y^2$ **Solution**: First, find both partial derivatives: $\begin{align} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}} (\sin(\blueE{x})y^2) &= \cos(\blueE{x})y^2 \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}} (\sin(x)\redE{y}^2) &= 2\sin(x)\redE{y} \end{align}$ Then for each one, write both partial derivatives: $\begin{align} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}(\sin(x)y^2) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}(\cos(\blueE{x})y^2) = -\sin(\blueE{x})y^2 \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y}(\sin(x)y^2) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}(2\sin(\blueE{x})y) = 2\cos(\blueE{x})y \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}(\sin(x)y^2) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}}(\cos(x)\redE{y}^2) = 2\cos(x)\redE{y} \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y}(\sin(x)y^2) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{y}}(2\sin(x)\redE{y}) = 2\sin(x) \end{align}$ $\begin{array}{ccccccc} &\large\sin(x)y^2 \\\\ &\small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}\large\swarrow\quad\searrow\small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \\\\ &\large\cos(x)y^2\qquad\qquad\qquad 2\sin(x)y \\\\ \small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}\large\swarrow&\large\searrow\small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial y}\qquad\qquad\qquad\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}\large\swarrow&\large\searrow\small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \\\\ \large\sin(x)y^2&\large\maroonD{\underbrace{\blueE{2\cos(x)y\qquad2\cos(x)y}}_{\text{Mixed partial derivatives are the same!}}}&\large2\sin(x) \end{array}$ ## Symmetry of second derivatives Notice, in the example above, the two mixed partial derivatives $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}$ and $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}$ are the same. This is not a coincidence; it happens for almost every function you encounter in practice. For example, look at what happens to a general polynomial term $x^n y^k$: $\begin{align} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redD{y}}(\blueE{x}^n \redD{y}^k) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}(k \blueE{x}^n \redD{y}^{k-1}) = nk \blueE{x}^{n-1} \redD{y}^{k-1} \\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redD{y}}\left( \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{x}}(\blueE{x}^n \redD{y}^k) \right) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redD{y}}(n \blueE{x}^{n-1} \redD{y}^k) = nk \blueE{x}^{n-1} \redD{y}^{k-1} \end{align}$ Technically, the symmetry of second derivatives is not always true. There is a theorem, referred to variously as Schwarz's theorem or Clairaut's theorem, which states that symmetry of second derivatives will always hold at a point if the second partial derivatives are *continuous* around that point. To really get into the meat of this, we'd need some real analysis. You should keep in the back of your mind that exceptions exist, but the symmetry of second derivatives work for just about every "normal" looking function that you will come across. [[☃ explanation 2]] ## Example 2: Higher order derivatives Why stop at second partial derivatives? We could also take, say, five partial derivatives with respect to various input variables. **Problem**: If $f(x, y, z) = \sin(xy)e^{x + z}$, what is $f_{zyzyx}$? **Solution**: The notation $f_{zyzyx}$ is shorthand for $((((f_z)_y)_z)_y)_x$, so we differentiate with respect to $z$, then with respect to $y$, then $z$, then $y$, then $x$. That is, we read **left to right**. It's worth pointing out that the order is different in the other notation: $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z} = \dfrac{\partial^5 f}{ \underbrace{\partial x}_{5^{th}} \underbrace{\partial y}_{4^{th}} \underbrace{\partial z}_{3^{rd}} \underbrace{\partial y}_{2^{nd}} \underbrace{\partial z}_{1^{st}} } \end{align}$ So the order of differentiation is indicated by the order of the terms in the denominator from **right to left**. Anyway, back to the problem at hand. This is one of those tasks where you just have to roll up your sleeves and slog through it, but to help things let's color the variables $\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}$ to keep track of where they all are: $\begin{align} \quad f(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ f_{\greenE{z}}(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \greenE{z}} \left( \sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \right) \\\\ &= \sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ f_{\greenE{z}\redD{y}}(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \redD{y}} \left( \sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \right) \\\\ &= \cos(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ f_{\greenE{z}\redD{y}\greenE{z}}(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \greenE{z}} \left( \cos(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \right) \\\\ &= \cos(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ f_{\greenE{z}\redD{y}\greenE{z}\redD{y}}(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \redD{y}} \left( \cos(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \right) \\\\ &= -\sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}^2 e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ f_{\greenE{z}\redD{y}\greenE{z}\redD{y}\blueD{x}}(\blueD{x}, \redD{y}, \greenE{z}) &= \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial \blueD{x}} \left( -\sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}^2 e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \right) \\\\ &= \underbrace{-\cos(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\redD{y}}_{ \small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} (-\sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})) }\blueD{x}^2 e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ &\phantom{=}-\sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y}) \underbrace{2\blueD{x}}_{ \small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}\blueD{x}^2 }e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} \\\\ &\phantom{=}-\sin(\blueD{x}\redD{y})\blueD{x}^2 \underbrace{e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}}}_{ \small\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} e^{\blueD{x} + \greenE{z}} } \end{align}$ This last step uses the extended product rule, $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(f(x)g(x)h(x)\Big) \\\\ &= f'(x)g(x)h(x) + f(x)g'(x)h(x) + f(x)g(x)h'(x) \end{align}$ Man! That was a tedious example. But if you could follow all the way through, computing multiple partial derivatives should not be an issue for you. It's one of those things that just requires more bookkeeping than anything else.

## Background - [Partial derivatives](partial-derivatives/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives) - [Gradient](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/the-gradient) ## What we're building to - If you have some multivariable function, $f(x, y)$ and some vector in the function's input space, $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, the directional derivative of $f$ along $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ tells you the rate at which $f$ will change while the input moves with velocity vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. [[☃ image 1]] - The notation here is $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$, and it is computed by taking the dot product between the gradient of $f$ and the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, that is, $
abla f \cdot \vec{	extbf{v}}$ - When the directional derivative is used to compute slope, be sure to normalize the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ first. ## Generalizing partial derivatives Consider some multivariable function: $f(x, y) = x^2 - xy$ We know that the [partial derivatives](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives) with respect to $x$ and $y$ tell us the rate of change of $f$ as we nudge the input either in the $x$ or $y$ direction. [[☃ explanation 1]] The question now is what happens when we nudge the input of $f$ in a direction which is not parallel to the $x$ or $y$ axes. For example, the image below shows the graph of $f$ along with a small step along a vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ in the input space, meaning the $xy$-plane in this case. Is there an operation which tells us how the height of the graph above the tip of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ compares to the height of the graph above its tail? [[☃ image 6]] As you have probably guessed, there is a new type of derivative, called the **directional derivative**, which answers this question. Just as the partial derivative is taken with respect to some input variable—e.g., $x$ or $y$—the directional derivative is taken *along* some vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ in the input space. One very helpful way to think about this is to picture a point in the input space moving with velocity $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. The directional derivative of $f$ along $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ is the resulting rate of change in the output of the function. So, for example, multiplying the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ by two would double the value of the directional derivative since all changes would be happening twice as fast. ## Notation There are quite a few different notations for this one concept: - $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$ - $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial{\vec{	extbf{v}}}}$ - $f'_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}$ - $D_{\vec{	extbf{v}}f}$ - $\partial_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$ All of these represent the same thing: the rate of change of $f$ as you nudge the input along the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. We'll use the $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$ notation, just because it subtly hints at how you compute the directional derivative using the gradient, which you'll see in a moment. ## Example 1: $\vec{	extbf{v}} = \hat{	extbf{j}}$ Before jumping into the general rule for computing $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$, let's look at how we can rewrite the more familiar notion of a partial derivative as a directional derivative. [[☃ image 2]] For example, the partial derivative $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}$ tells us the rate at which $f$ changes as we nudge the input in the $y$ direction. In other words, as we nudge it along the vector $\hat{	extbf{j}}$. Therefore, we could equivalently write the partial derivative with respect to $y$ as $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} = 
abla_{\hat{	extbf{j}}} f$. This is all just fiddling with different notation. What's more important is to have a clear mental image of what all this notation​ *represents*. **Reflection Question**: Suppose $\vec{	extbf{v}} = \hat{	extbf{i}} + \hat{	extbf{j}}$, what is your best guess for $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f\,$? [[☃ explanation 2]] ## How to compute the directional derivative Let's say you have a multivariable $f(x, y, z)$ which takes in three variables—$x$, $y$ and $z$—and you want to compute its directional derivative along the following vector: $ \vec{	extbf{v}} = \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{2} \ edE{3} \ \greenE{-1} \end{array} ight] $ The answer, as it turns out, is $ 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f =  lueE{2} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} + edE{3} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} + \greenE{(-1)} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z} $ This should make sense because a tiny nudge along $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ can be broken down into $ lueE{two}$ tiny nudges in the $x$-direction, $edE{three}$ tiny nudges in the $y$-direction, and a tiny nudge backwards, by $\greenE{-1}$, in the $z$-direction. We'll go through the rigorous reasoning behind this much more thoroughly in the [next article](g/a/directional-derivatives-going-deeper). More generally, we can write the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ abstractly as follows: $ \vec{	extbf{v}} = \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{v_1} \ edE{v_2} \ \greenE{v_3} \end{array} ight] $ The directional derivative looks like this: $ 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f =  lueE{v_1} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} + edE{v_2} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} + \greenE{v_3} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z} $ That is, a tiny nudge in the $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ direction consists of $ lueE{v_1}$ times a tiny nudge in the $x$-direction, $edE{v_2}$ times a tiny nudge in the $y$-direction, and $\greenE{v_3}$ times a tiny nudge in the $z$-direction. This can be written in a super-pleasing compact way using the dot product and the gradient: $ egin{align} &\phantom{=}
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(x, y, z) \\ &=  lueE{v_1} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x, y, z) + edE{v_2} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x, y, z) + \greenE{v_3} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x, y, z) \\ &= \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x, y, z) \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x, y, z) \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x, y, z) \end{array} ight] \cdot \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{v_1} \\ edE{v_2} \\ \greenE{v_3} \end{array} ight] \\ &= 
abla f(x, y, z) \cdot \vec{	extbf{v}} \end{align}$ This is why the notation $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}$ is so suggestive of the way we compute the directional derivative: $ egin{align} 
abla_{\maroonD{\vec{	extbf{v}}}} f = 
abla f \cdot \maroonD{\vec{	extbf{v}}} \end{align}$ Take a moment to delight in the fact that one single operation, the gradient, packs enough information to compute the rate of change of a function in *every possible direction!* That's so many directions! Left, right, up, down, north-north-east, 34.8$^\circ$ clockwise from the $x$-axis... Madness! ## Example 2: **Problem**: Take a look at the following function. $f(x, y) = x^2 - xy$, What is the directional derivative of $f$ at the point $(2, -3)$ along the vector $ egin{align} \vec{	extbf{v}} =  lueE{0.6} \hat{	extbf{i}} + edE{0.8} \hat{	extbf{j}} \end{align}$? **Solution**: You can think of the direction derivative either as a weighted sum of partial derivatives, as below: $ egin{align} 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f =  lueE{0.6} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} + edE{0.8} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \end{align}$ Or, you can think of it as a dot product with the gradient, as you see here: $ egin{align} 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f = 
abla f \cdot \vec{	extbf{v}} \end{align}$ The first is faster, but just for practice, let's see how the gradient interpretation unfolds. We start by computing the gradient itself: $ 
abla f = \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} \ \ \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} \ \end{array} ight] = \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial }{ lueE{\partial x}} ( lueE{x}^2 -  lueE{x}y) \ \ \dfrac{\partial}{edE{\partial y}} (x^2 - xedE{y}) \ \end{array} ight] = \left[  egin{array}{c} 2 lueE{x} - y \ -x \end{array} ight] $ Next, plug in the point $(x, y) = (2, -3)$ since this is the point the question asks us about. $ egin{align} 
abla f(2, -3) = \left[ egin{array}{c} 2(2) - (-3) \\ -(2) \end{array} ight] = \left[ egin{array}{c} 7 \\ -2 \end{array} ight] \end{align}$ To get the desired directional derivative, we take the dot product between this gradient and $	extbf{v}$: $ egin{align} 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(2, -3) &= 
abla f(2, -3) \cdot \left(  lueE{0.6} \hat{	extbf{i}} + edE{0.8} \hat{	extbf{j}} ight) \\ &= \left[  egin{array}{c} 7 \\ -2 \end{array} ight] \cdot \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{0.6} \\ edE{0.8} \end{array} ight] \\ &= 7( lueE{0.6}) + (-2)(edE{0.8}) \\ &= 2.6 \end{align}$ ## Finding slope How do you find the slope of a graph intersected with a plane that is not parallel to the $x$ or $y$ axes? [[☃ image 2]] You can use the directional derivative, but there is one important thing to remember: *If the directional derivative is used to compute slope, either $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ must be a unit vector or you must remember to divide by $||\vec{	extbf{v}}||$ at the end*. In the definition and computation above, doubling the length of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ would double the value of the directional derivative. In terms of the computation, this is because $
abla f \cdot (2\vec{	extbf{v}}) = 2(
abla f \cdot v)$. However, this might not always be what you want. The slope of a graph in the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, for example, depends only on the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, not the magnitude $||\vec{	extbf{v}}||$. Let's see why. How can we imagine this slope? Slice the graph of $f$ with a vertical plane that cuts the $xy$-plane in the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. The slope in question is that of a line tangent to the resulting curve. As with any slope, we look for the rise over run. [[☃ image 3]] In this case, the run will be the distance of a small nudge in the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. We can express such a nudge as an addition of $h\vec{	extbf{v}}$ to an input point $	extbf{x}_0$, where $h$ is thought of as some small number. The magnitude of this nudge is $h ||\vec{	extbf{v}}||$. The resulting change in the output of $f$ can be approximated by multiplying this little value $h$ by the directional derivative: $h 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(x_0, y_0)$ In fact, the rise of the tangent line—as opposed to the graph of the function— is *precisely* $h 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(x_0, y_0)$ due to this run of size $h ||\vec{	extbf{v}}||$. For full details on why this is true, see the formal definition of the directional derivative in the [next article](g/a/directional-derivatives-going-deeper). Therefore, the rise-over-run slope of our graph is $ egin{align} \dfrac{h
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f(x_0, y_0)}{h||v||} =  oxed{\dfrac{
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f(x_0, y_0)}{||v||}} \end{align}$ Notice, if $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ is a unit vector, meaning $||\vec{	extbf{v}}|| = 1$, then the directional derivative *does* give the slope of a graph along that direction. Otherwise, it is important to remember to divide out by the magnitude of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. Some authors even go so far as to include normalization in the definition of $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f$. **Alternate definition of directional derivative:** $ egin{align} 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(	extbf{x}) = \lim_{h 	o 0}\dfrac{f(	extbf{x} + h\vec{	extbf{v}}) - f(	extbf{x})}{h lueE{||\vec{	extbf{v}}||}} \end{align}$ Personally, I think this definition puts too much emphasis on the particular use case of finding slope, so I prefer to use the original definition and normalize $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ when necessary. ## Example 3: Slope **Problem**: On the stage for this problem we have three players. Player 1, the function: $f(x, y) = \sin(xy)$ Player 2, the point: $(x_0, y_0) = \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}, \dfrac{1}{2}ight)$ Player 3, the vector: $\vec{	extbf{v}} = 2 \hat{	extbf{i}} + 3 \hat{	extbf{j}}$ What is the slope of the graph of $f$ at the point $(x_0, y_0)$ along the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$? **Answer**: Since we are finding slope, we must first normalize the vector in question. The magnitude $||\vec	extbf{v}||$ is $\sqrt{2^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{13}$, so we divide each term by $\sqrt{13}$ to get the resulting unit vector $\hat{	extbf{u}}$ in the direction of $\vec	extbf{v}$: [[☃ explanation 1]] Next, find the gradient of $f$: [[☃ explanation 5]] Plug in the point $(x_0, y_0) = \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}, \dfrac{1}{2}ight)$ to this gradient. [[☃ explanation 1]] Finally, take the dot product between $\hat{	extbf{u}}$ and $
abla f(\pi/3, 1/2)$: [[☃ explanation 1]] ## Summary - If you have some multivariable function, $f(x, y)$ and some vector in the function's input space, $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, the directional derivative of $f$ along $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ tells you the rate at which $f$ will change while the input moves with velocity vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. - The notation here is $
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f$, and it is computed by taking the dot product between the gradient of $f$ and the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$, that is, $
abla f \cdot \vec{	extbf{v}}$. - When the directional derivative is used to compute slope, be sure to normalize the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$ first.

##Background: - [Introduction to directional derivatives](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/directional-derivative-introduction) - [Partial derivatives](partial-derivatives/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives/) - [Gradient](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/the-gradient) This article is targetted for those who want a deeper understanding of the directional derivative and its formula. ## Formal definition of the directional derivative There are a couple reasons you might care about a formal definition. For one thing, really understanding the formal definition of a new concept can make clear what it is really going on. But more importantly than that, I think the main benefit is that it gives you the confidence to recognize when such a concept can and cannot be applied. As a warm up, let's review the formal definition of the partial derivative, say with respect to $x$: $ \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}(x_0, y_0) = \lim_{h 	o 0} \dfrac{f(x_0  lueE{+ h}, y_0) - f(x_0, y_0)}{ lueE{h}} $ The connection between the informal way to read $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ and the formal way to read the right-hand side is as follows: **Symbol** | **Informal understanding** | **Formal understanding** -|-|- $\partial x$ | A tiny nudge in the $x$ direction. | A limiting variable $h$ which goes to $0$, and will be added to the first component of the function's input. $\partial f$ | The resulting change in the output of $f$ after the nudge. | The difference between $f(x_0 + h, y_0)$ and $f(x_0, y_0)$, taken in the same limit as $h 	o 0$. We could instead write this in vector notation, viewing the input point $(x_0, y_0)$ as a two-dimensional vector $ egin{align} 	extbf{x}_0 = \left[  egin{array}{c} x_0 \\ y_0 \\ \end{array} ight] \end{align}$ Here $	extbf{x}_0$ is written in bold to emphasize its vectoriness. It's a bit confusing to use a bold $	extbf{x}$ for the entire input rather than some other letter, since the letter $x$ is already used in an un-bolded form to denote the first component of the input. But hey, that's convention, so we go with it. Instead of writing the "nudged" input as $(x_0 + h, y_0)$, we write it as $	extbf{x}_0 + h \hat{	extbf{i}}$, where $\hat{	extbf{i}}$ is the unit vector in the $x$-direction: $ egin{align} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(	extbf{x}_0) = \lim_{h 	o 0} \dfrac{f(	extbf{x}_0 + h \hat{	extbf{i}}) - f(	extbf{x}_0)}{h} \end{align}$ In this notation, it's much easier to see how to generalize the partial derivative with respect to $x$ to the directional derivative along any vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$: $  lueE{ 
abla_edD{\vec{	extbf{v}}}f(	extbf{x}_0) = \lim_{h 	o 0} \dfrac{f(	extbf{x}_0 + hedD{\vec{	extbf{v}}}) - f(	extbf{x}_0)}{h} } $ In this case, adding $h \vec{	extbf{v}}$ to the input for a limiting variable $h 	o 0$ formalizes the idea of a tiny nudge in the direction of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. [[☃ image 1]] ## Seeking connection between the definition and computation Computing the directional derivative involves a dot product between the gradient $
abla f$ and the vector $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. For example, in two dimensions, here's what this would look like: $ egin{align} 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(x, y) &= 
abla f \cdot \vec{	extbf{v}} \\ &= \left[  egin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \end{array} ight] \cdot \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{v_1} \\ \greenE{v_2} \end{array} ight] \\ &=  lueE{v_1} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x, y) + \greenE{v_2} \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x, y) \end{align}$ Here, $ lueE{v_1}$ and $\greenE{v_2}$ are the components of $\vec{	extbf{v}}$. $ egin{align} \vec{	extbf{v}} = \left[  egin{array}{c}  lueE{v_1} \ \ \greenE{v_2} \\ \end{array} ight] \end{align}$ The central question is, what does this formula have to do with the definition given above? ## Breaking down the nudge The computation for $
abla_	extbf{v} f$ can be seen as a way to break down a tiny step in the direction of $	extbf{v}$ into its $x$ and $y$ components. [[☃ image 2]] Specifically, you can imagine the following procedure: 1. Start at some point $(x_0, y_0)$. - Choose a tiny value $h$. - Add $h lueE{v_1}$ to $x_0$, which means stepping to the point $(x_0 + h lueE{v_1}, y_0)$. From what we know of [partial derivatives](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives), this will change the output of the function by about $ egin{align} h lueE{v_1} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0, y_0) ight) \end{align}$ - Now add $h\greenE{v_2}$ to $y_0$ to bring us up/down to the point $(x_0 +h lueE{v_1}, y_0 + h\greenE{v_2})$. The resulting change to $f$ is now about $ egin{align} h\greenE{v_2}\left( \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0 + h lueE{v_1}, y_0) ight) \end{align}$ Adding the results of steps $3$ and $4$, the total change to the function upon moving from the input $(x_0, y_0)$ to the input $(x_0 +h lueE{v_1}, y_0 + h\greenE{v_2})$ has been about $ egin{align} h lueE{v_1} \left(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0, y_0) ight) + h\greenE{v_2}\left( \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0 edD{+ h lueE{v_1}}, y_0) ight) \end{align}$ This is very close to the expression for the directional derivative, which says the change in $f$ due to this step $h \vec{	extbf{v}}$ should be about $ egin{align} &\phantom{=}h 
abla_{\vec{	extbf{v}}} f(x_0, y_0) \\ &= h \vec{	extbf{v}} \cdot 
abla f(x_0, y_0)\\ &= h lueE{v_1}\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0, y_0) + h\greenE{v_2}\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0, y_0) \end{align}$ However, this differs slightly from the result of our step-by-step argument, in which the partial derivative with respect to $y$ is taken at the point $(x_0 + h lueE{v_1}, y_0)$, not at the point $(x_0, y_0)$. Luckily we are considering very, very small values of $h$. In fact, more technically, we should be talking about the limit as $h 	o 0$. Therefore evaluating $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}$ at $(x_0 + h lueE{v_1}, y_0)$ will be almost the same as evaluating it at $(x_0, y_0)$. Moreover, as $h$ approaches $0$, so does the difference between these two, but we have to assume that $f$ is continuous. ## Why does the gradient point in the direction of steepest ascent? Having learned about the directional derivatives, we can now understand *why* the direction of the [gradient](partial-derivatives-and-the-gradient/a/the-gradient) is the direction of steepest ascent. [[☃ image 1]] Specifically, here's the question at hand. **Setup**: - Let $f$ be some scalar-valued multivariable function, such as $f(x, y) = x^2 + y^2$. - Let $(x_0, y_0)$ be a particular input point - Consider all possible *directions*, i.e. all unit vectors $\hat{	extbf{u}}$ in the input space of $f$. **Question (informal)**: If we start at $(x_0, y_0)$, which direction should we walk so that the output of $f$ increases most quickly? **Question (formal)**: Which unit vector $\hat{	extbf{u}}$ maximizes the directional derivative along $\hat{	extbf{u}}$? $ egin{align} 
abla_{\hat{	extbf{u}}} f(x_0, y_0) = \underbrace{\hat{	extbf{u}} \cdot 
abla f(x_0, y_0)}_{ 	ext{Maximize this quantity} } \end{align}$ The famous triangle inequality tells us that this will be maximized by the unit vector in the direction $
abla f(x_0, y_0)$. [[☃ image 5]] Notice, the fact that the gradient points in the direction of steepest ascent is a consequence of the more fundamental fact that all directional derivatives require taking the dot product with $
abla f$. [[☃ explanation 2]]

## Background - [(Ordinary) derivatives](/taking-derivatives-calc) - [Multivariable functions](/what-are-multivariable-functions/a/multivariable-functions) - [Graphs of multivariable function](/ways-to-represent-multivariable-functions/a/graphs) ## What we're building to - For a multivariable function, like $f(x, y) = x^2y$, computing partial derivatives looks something like this: $ egin{align} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} &= \!\!\!\!\! \underbrace{ \dfrac{\partial}{ lueE{\partial x}}  lueE{x^2}y }_{\substack{ 	ext{Treat }y	ext{ as constant;}\\ 	ext{take derivative.} }}\!\!\!\!\! = 2 lueE{x}y \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} &= \!\!\!\!\! \underbrace{ \dfrac{\partial}{edE{\partial y}} x^2edE{y} }_{\substack{ 	ext{Treat }x	ext{ as constant;}\\ 	ext{take derivative.} }}\!\!\!\!\! = x^2\cdot edE{1} \end{align}$ - This swirly-d symbol, $\partial $, often called "del", is used to distinguish partial derivatives from ordinary single-variable derivatives. Or, should I say ... to differentiate them. - The reason for a new type of derivative is that when the input of a function is made up of multiple variables, we want to see how the function changes as we *let just one of those variables change* while holding all the others constant. - With respect to three-dimensional graphs, you can picture the partial derivative $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ by slicing the graph of $f$ with a plane representing a constant $y$-value and measuring the slope of the resulting curve along the cut. [[☃ image 1]] ## What is a *partial* derivative? We'll assume you are familiar with the ordinary derivative $\dfrac{df}{dx}$ from single variable calculus. I actually quite like this notation for the derivative, because you can interpret it as follows: - Interpret $dx$ as "a very tiny change in $x$". - Interpret $df$ as "a very tiny change in the output of $f$", where it is understood that this tiny change is whatever results from the tiny change $dx$ to the input. In fact, I think this intuitive feel for the symbol $\dfrac{df}{dx}$ is one of the most useful takeaways from single-variable calculus, and when you really start feeling it in your bones, most of the concepts around derivatives start to click. For example, when you apply it to the graph of $f$, you can interpret this "ratio" $\dfrac{df}{dx}$ as the rise-over-run slope of the graph of $f$, which depends on the point where you started. [[☃ image 9]] ### How does this work for multivariable functions? Consider some function with a two-dimensional input and a one-dimensional output. $f(x, y) = x^2-2xy$ There's nothing stopping us from writing the same expression, $\dfrac{df}{dx}$, and interpreting it the same way: - $dx$ can still represent a tiny change in the variable $x$, which is now just one component of our input. - $df$ can still represent the resulting change to the output of the function $f(x, y)$. However, this ignores the fact that there is another input variable $y$. The input space now has multiple dimensions, so we can change the input in many directions other than the $x$-direction. For example, what about changing $y$ slightly by some small value $dy$? Now if we re-interpret $df$ to represent the tiny change to the function that this $dy$ shift brings about, we would have a different derivative $\dfrac{df}{dy}$. [[☃ image 7]] Neither one of these derivatives tells the full story of how our function $f(x, y)$ changes when its input changes slightly, so we call them **partial derivatives**. To emphasize the difference, *we no longer use the letter $d$ to indicate tiny changes, but instead introduce a newfangled symbol $\partial$* to do the trick, writing each partial derivative as $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$, $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}$, etc. You read the symbol $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ out loud by saying "the partial derivative of $f$ with respect to $x$". $ egin{array}{c} 	ext{Can be thought of as } \ 	ext{"a tiny change in} \ 	ext{the function's output"} \\  egin{array}{c}  egin{array}{c}  lueE{	ext{Used instead of "d" in}} \  lueE{	ext{usual }\dfrac{df}{dx}	ext{ notation to}} \  lueE{	ext{emphasize that this is}} \  lueE{	ext{a partial derivative.}} \end{array} &  egin{array}{c} \LARGE lueE
earrow^{\huge\,\overbrace{ lueE\partial \greenE f}\,}\greenE 
warrow \\ \Huge 	ext{	extemdash} \\ \LARGE lueE\searrow_{\huge\,\underbrace{ lueE\partial \maroonE x}\,}\maroonE \swarrow \end{array} &  egin{array}{c} \\ \greenE{	ext{Multivariable}} \ \greenE{	ext{function}} \\ \maroonE{	ext{Indicates which}} \ \maroonE{	ext{input variable}} \ \maroonE{	ext{is changed slightly.}} \end{array} \end{array} \\ 	ext{Can be thought of as} \ 	ext{"a tiny change in }x	ext{"} \end{array}$ ## Example: Computing a partial derivative Consider this function: $ f( lueE{x}, edE{y}) =  lueE{x}^2 edE{y}^3 $ Suppose I asked you to evaluate $\dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}$, the partial derivative with respect to $x$, at the input $( lueE{3}, edE{2})$. "What? But I haven't learned how yet!" Don't worry, it's mostly just the same mechanics as an ordinary derivative. From the introduction above, you should know that this is asking about the rate at which the output of $f$ changes as we nudge the $x$-component of the input slightly, perhaps moving from $( lueE{3}, edE{2})$ to $( lueE{3.01}, edE{2})$. Since we only care about movement in the $ lueE{x}$-direction, we might as well treat the $edE{y}$-value as a constant. In fact, we can just plug in $edE{y=2}$ ahead of time before computing any derivatives: $ f( lueE{x}, edE{2}) =  lueE{x}^2 (edE{2})^3 = 8 lueE{x}^2$ Now, asking how $f$ changes in response to a small shift in $ lueE{x}$ is just an ordinary, single-variable derivative. [[☃ graded-group 1]] ### Without pre-evaluating $y$ Now suppose I asked you to find $\dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}$, but I didn't ask you to evaluate it at a specific point. In other words, you should give me new multivariable function which takes *any* point $( lueE{x}, edE{y})$ as its input and tells me what the rate of change of $f$ near that point is as we move purely in the $ lueE{x}$-direction. You can start the same way, treating the $edE{y}$ value as a constant. However, this time, you cannot plug in an actual constant value, like $edE{y = 2}$. Instead, *pretend* that $edE{y}$ is ​constant and take the derivative: $ \dfrac{d}{ lueE{dx}}f( lueE{x}, y) = \underbrace{ \dfrac{d}{ lueE{dx}}( lueE{x}^2y^3) }_{	ext{Pretend }y	ext{ is constant}} = 2 lueE{x}y^3 $ Or rather, since to emphasize that this is a multivariable function, we use the symbol $\partial$ instead of $d$: $ \dfrac{\partial}{ lueE{\partial x}}f( lueE{x}, y) = \dfrac{\partial}{ lueE{\partial x}}( lueE{x}^2y^3) = 2 lueE{x}y^3 $ As a sanity check, you can plug in $( lueE{3}, edE{2})$ to see that we get the same result as above. "So, what's the difference between $\dfrac{d}{dx}$ and $\dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}$? They seem to be used the same way." Honestly, as far as I'm concerned, there's not really a difference between these operations. You could be pedantic and say one is only defined for single variable functions. But as far as intuition and computation go, they are one and the same, and the difference is just meant to clarify what *type* of function is being differentiated. ## Interpreting partial derivatives with graphs Consider this function: $f(x, y) = \dfrac{1}{5}(x^2 - 2xy) + 3$, Here is a video showing its graph rotating, just to get a feel for the three-dimensional nature of it. [[☃ video 2]] Think about the partial derivative of $f$ with respect to $ lueE{x}$, perhaps evaluated at the point $(2, 0)$. $ \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}(2, 0)$ In terms of the graph, what does the value of this expression tell us about the behavior of the function $f$ at the point $(2, 0)$? ### Treat $y$ as constant $ightarrow$ slice graph with plane The first step when computing this value is to treat $y$ as a constant. Specifically, if we are limiting our view to what happens at the point $(2, 0)$, we should only look at the set of points where $y = 0$. In three-dimensional space, this set is plane perpendicular to the $y$-axis, passing through the origin. [[☃ image 9]] This plane $y = 0$, shown in white, slices into the graph of $f(x,y)$ along a parabolic curve, shown faintly in red. We can interpret $\dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}$ as giving the slope of a tangent line to this curve. Why? Because $\partial x$ is a slight nudge in the $x$-direction, the run, and $\partial f$ is the resulting change in the $z$-direction, the rise. What about $\dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}}$ at that same point $(2, 0)$? The points where $ lueE{x=2}$ also make up a plane, but this time it's a plane perpendicular to the $x$-axis intersecting the point $x=2$. This slices the graph along a new curve, and $\dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}}$ will give the slope of that new curve. [[☃ image 10]] [[☃ graded-group 1]] [[☃ explanation 2]] ## Phrasing and notation Here are some of the phrases you might hear in reference to this $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ operation: - "The partial derivative of $f$ with respect to $x$" - "Del f, del x" - "Partial f, partial x" - "The partial derivative (of $f$) in the $x$-direction" ### Alternate notation In the same way that people sometimes prefer to write $f'$ instead of $\dfrac{df}{dx}$, we have the following notation: $ egin{align} f_ lueE{x} &\leftrightarrow \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} \\ f_edE{y} &\leftrightarrow \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} \\ f_{\greenE{\langle	ext{Some variable }angle}} &\leftrightarrow \dfrac{\partial f}{\greenE{\partial \langle	ext{That same variable} angle}} \end{align}$ ### A note about "del" While it's common to refer to the partial symbol $\partial$ as "del", this can be confusing because "del" is also the name of the Nabla symbol $
abla$, which we will introduce in the next article. ## A more formal definition Although thinking of $dx$ or $\partial x$ as really tiny changes in the value of $x$ is a useful intuition, it is healthy to occasionally step back and remember that defining things precisely requires introducing limits. After all, what specific small value would $\partial x$ be? One one hundredth? One one millionth? $10^{-10^{10}}$? The point of calculus is that we don't use any one tiny number, but instead consider all possible values and analyze what tends to happen as they approach a limiting value. The single variable derivative, for example, is defined like this: $ egin{align} \dfrac{{df}}{ lueE{dx}}(x_0) = \lim_{ lueE{h}	o 0} \dfrac{{f(x_0 lueE{+h}) - f(x_0)}}{ lueE{h}} \end{align}$ - $h$ represents the "tiny value" that we intuitively think of as $dx$. - The $h 	o 0$ under the limit indicates that we care about very small values of $h$, those approaching $0$. - $f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)$ is the change in the output that results from adding $h$ to the input, which is what we think of as $df$. Formally defining the partial derivative looks almost identical. If $f(x, y, \dots)$ is a function with multiple inputs, here's how that looks: $ egin{align} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}}(x_0, y_0, \dots) &= \lim_{ lueE{h} 	o 0} \dfrac{f( lueE{x_0 lueE{+h}}, y_0, \dots) - f(x_0, y_0, \dots)} { lueE{h}} \end{align}$ Similarly, here's how the partial derivative with respect to $y$ looks: $ egin{align} \dfrac{\partial f}{edD{\partial y}}(x_0, y_0, \dots) &= \lim_{edD{h} 	o 0} \dfrac{f(x_0, edD{y_0+h}, \dots) - f(x_0, y_0, \dots)}{edD{h}} \end{align}$ The point is that $h$, which represents a tiny tweak to the input, is added to different input variables depending on which partial derivative we are taking. People will often refer to this as the **limit definition** of a partial derivative. **Reflection question**: How can we think about this limit definition in the context of the graphical interpretation above? What is $h$? What does it look like for $h 	o 0$? ## Summary - For a multivariable function, like $f(x, y) = x^2y$, computing partial derivatives looks something like this: $ egin{align} \dfrac{\partial f}{ lueE{\partial x}} &= \!\!\!\!\! \underbrace{ \dfrac{\partial}{ lueE{\partial x}}  lueE{x^2}y }_{\substack{ 	ext{Treat }y	ext{ as constant;}\\ 	ext{take derivative.} }}\!\!\!\!\! = 2 lueE{x}y \\ \dfrac{\partial f}{edE{\partial y}} &= \!\!\!\!\! \underbrace{ \dfrac{\partial}{edE{\partial y}} x^2edE{y} }_{\substack{ 	ext{Treat }x	ext{ as constant;}\\ 	ext{take derivative.} }}\!\!\!\!\! = x^2\cdot edE{1} \end{align}$ - This swirly-d symbol $\partial $, often called "del", is used to distinguish partial derivatives from ordinary single-variable derivatives. - The reason for a new type of derivative is that when the input of a function is made up of multiple variables, we want to see how the function changes as we *let just one of those variables change* while holding all the others constant. - With respect to three-dimensional graphs, you can picture the partial derivative $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$ by slicing the graph of $f$ with a plane representing a constant $y$-value, and measuring the slope of the resulting cut. [[☃ image 2]]

you take a nudge in that direction.

you're thinking of v of t, and you're thinking

as you zip along is what determines

and of the multivariable chain rule.

minus s times t-squared, minus s times t-squared.

of a guy like this, is actually relatively straight-forward.
If you're to just guess what it might mean,
you'll probably guess right.

one of its input variables, and I'll choose t
with respect to t.

scaler valued function.

t-squared looks like a variable,

S times t, when s looks like a constant
and when t looks like a variable,
has a derivative of s.
Then t times s-squared, when t's the variable
and s is the constant, just looks like that constant,
which is s-squared minus s times t-squared.
So now a derivative of t-squared is 2t
and that constant s stays in.
So that two times s times t.

probably relatively straightforward.

It's one of those things where sometimes you'll even see

kind of leaving it understood to the reader that,
yeah, P and Q always refer to the x and y components

it's actually the one that I used in the last video.
P is equal to x times y,

slide.text: ## Background - [Derivatives of vector-valued functions](differentiating-vector-valued-functions/a/derivatives-of-vector-valued-functions) ## What we're building to [[☃ image 1]] - The radius of curvature at a point on a curve is, loosely speaking, the radius of a circle which fits the curve most snugly at that point. - The **curvature**, denoted $\kappa$, is one divided by the radius of curvature. - In formulas, curvature is defined as the magnitude of the derivative of a unit tangent vector function with respect to arc length: $\kappa = \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right|$ Don't worry, I'll talk about each step of computing this value. - The intuition here is that the unit tangent vector tells you which direction you are moving, and the rate at which it changes with respect to small steps $ds$ along the curve is a good indication of how quickly you are turning. ## Driving along a curve Picture some curve in the $xy$-plane. We'll treat everything with formulas in a bit, but for now, just think of the picture: [[☃ image 2]] Imagine driving a car along this curve, and think of how much you would be turning the steering wheel at each point. At some points, the road hardly curves, and you are practically​ driving straight. At others, you have to turn the wheel quite a bit. Now imagine that at some time while you drive, your steering wheel locks. If you were to keep driving with this locked steering wheel, not at all minding the fact that you're going off the road, your car would trace out some circle, like the one drawn in green below: [[☃ image 4]] If the steering wheel was turned a lot when it froze, that circle would have a relatively small radius. If you were hardly turning at all, the circle would have a very large radius. The following animation shows what those various circles (drawn in green) might look like at different points on the curve. The radius of each circle is drawn in red. [[☃ video 1]] We call the radius of the circle associated with each point the **radius of curvature** at that point. It's a good way to measure how much a curve actually, you know, *curves* at each point. Another way to think about these circles is that they hug the curve more closely than any other circle would. Another important term is **curvature**, which is just one divided by the radius of curvature. It's typically denoted with the funky-looking little $\kappa$ symbol: $\kappa = \dfrac{1}{R}$ **Concept check**: When a curve is very close to being a straight line, the curvature would be [[☃ graded-group 1]] [[☃ explanation 1]] ## Computing curvature Suppose you have the function which defines a curve in the $xy$-plane. For example, the curve I used in the previous section is defined by the following vector-valued function: > $ \vec{\textbf{s}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} t - \sin(t) \\ 1 - \cos(t) \end{array} \right] $ This is the same thing as saying it is defined by the following parametric equations: > $\begin{align} \quad x(t) &= t - \sin(t) \\ y(t) &= 1 - \cos(t) \end{align}$ Computing curvature involves two broad steps: #### Step 1: Find a unit tangent vector A "unit tangent vector" to the curve at a point is, unsurprisingly​, a tangent vector with length $1$. In the context of a parametric curve defined by $\vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$, "finding a unit tangent vector" almost always means finding *all* unit tangent vectors. That is to say, defining a vector-valued function $T(t)$, which takes in the same parameter and spits out a unit vector which is tangent to the curve at the point $\vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$. [[☃ image 4]] #### Step 2: Find $\dfrac{dT}{ds}$ As you travel along the curve according to $\vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$, the unit vector changes direction whenever you turn. At sharp turns, it changes a lot, on relatively straight portions, it hardly changes at all. In fact, the curvature $\kappa$ is *defined* to be the derivative of the unit tangent vector function. However, it is not the derivative with respect to the parameter $t$, since that could depend on how quickly you are moving along the curve. It is the derivative with respect to tiny changes in *arc length*, usually represent with the letter $s$. > $\kappa = \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right|$ Typically, the way to compute this is by first taking the derivative of $T$ with respect to $t$, then dividing it by $||\dfrac{d\vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt}||$. > $ \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right| = \dfrac{ \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{dt} \right|\right| }{ \left|\left| \dfrac{d\vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt} \right|\right| } $ ## Finding the unit tangent vector Let's take a look at the function we had above: > $ \vec{\textbf{s}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} t - \sin(t) \\ 1 - \cos(t) \end{array} \right] $ If you read the article on [differentiating vector-valued functions](differentiating-vector-valued-functions/a/derivatives-of-vector-valued-functions), you will know that the derivative of this function can be thought of as a velocity vector. > $ \dfrac{d\vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt} = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{d}{dt}(t - \sin(t)) \\ \\ \dfrac{d}{dt}(1 - \cos(t)) \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 - \cos(t) \\ \sin(t) \end{array} \right] $ For example, if we evaluate the derivative we just calculated at a specific time, perhaps $t = \pi$, here's the vector we get: $\begin{align} \quad \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 - \cos(\pi) \\ \sin(\pi) \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ Positioning this vector so that its tail sits on the point $\vec{\textbf{s}}(\pi)$, where the particle is at time $t=\pi$, it represents the velocity of the particle at that time. [[☃ image 1]] However, we must tweak this function, since we want *unit* tangent vectors. For example, this particular tangent vector has length $2$, and $2 \ne 1^{\blueE{\text{[citation needed]}}}$. **Concept check**: Given the formula I just showed for of $\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)$, $\begin{align} \quad \vec{\textbf{s}}'(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 - \cos(t) \\ \sin(t) \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ what is the magnitude of this vector (as a function of time)? > [[☃ graded-group 1]] > [[☃ explanation 1]] **Concept check**: What is the unit vector pointing in the same direction as $\vec{\textbf{v}} = \left[\begin{array} \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right]$? (This specific vector is not related to our problem at hand, this is just practice with unit vectors). > [[☃ graded-group 2]] > [[☃ explanation 2]] ** Key question**:Which of the following represents the unit tangent vector of a curve parameterized by $\vec{\textbf{s}}$ (as a function of time)? > [[☃ graded-group 3]] > [[☃ explanation 3]] ## Getting curvature from the unit tangent vector Now we have an expression for the unit tangent vector as a function of time, which I'll denote with a capital $T$ for tangent, (not to be confused with lower-case $t$ for the parameter): $\begin{align} \quad T(t) = \dfrac{\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)}{||\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)||} \end{align}$ The curvature $\kappa$ is the magnitude of the derivative of this unit tangent vector, but with respect to arc length $s$, not the parameter $t$. $\begin{align} \quad \kappa = \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right| \end{align}$ Nevertheless, the typical way to compute this is to first differentiation $T$ with respect to $t$, then to divide by the magnitude $||\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)||$, which you can think of as $\dfrac{ds}{dt}$. > $ \kappa = \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right| = \dfrac{ \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{dt} \right|\right| }{ \left|\left| \dfrac{d\vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt} \right|\right| } $ ## Intuition Let's pause for a moment to get an intuition for this. The derivative of $T(t)$ tells us how the unit tangent vector changes over time. Since it's always a *unit* tangent vector, it never changes length, and only changes direction. [[☃ image 1]] At a particular time $t_0$, you can think of the vector $\dfrac{dT}{dt}(t_0)$ as sitting at the tip of the vector $T(t_0)$. Imagine the derivative vector trying to pull the vector $T(t_0)$ one way or another, telling it, "Hey! Come point more in this direction." Since the length of $T(t_0)$ never changes, this derivative vector must always be perpendicular to $T(t_0)$; otherwise. it would "pull" it longer or shorter. When this derivative vector is long, it's pulling the unit tangent vector *really* hard to change direction. As a result, the curve will change direction more suddenly, meaning it will have a smaller radius of curvature, and hence a very large curvature. Conversely, if the derivative vector is short, it's only half-heartedly pulling on the tangent vector. This translates to a very gentle turn, and hence a large radius of curvature, meaning a small curvature. However, we don't want differences in the rate at which we move along the curve to influence the value of curvature since it is a statement about the geometry of the curve itself and not the time-dependent trajectory of whatever particle happens to be traversing it. For this reason, curvature requires differentiating $T$ with respect to arc length, $s$, instead of the parameter $t$. ## Example: Curvature of a helix There's nothing specific about two-dimensions in everything we've just done. For example, let's find the curvature of the following three-dimensional function: $\begin{align} \quad \vec{\textbf{v}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \cos(t) \\ \sin(t) \\ t/5 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ The animation below shows the shape of this curve, which is known as a **helix**. It also indicates the radius of curvature at each point by showing the circle (drawn in green) which most closely "hugs" the curve at each point, with the radius of each circle drawn in red. [[☃ video 1]] Ah yes, I call this one "vector-calculus hula hoop dance." One thing you might notice is that the size of these circles doesn't seem to change. This is far from true for most three-dimensional curves, making our example somewhat special. **Concept check**: By seeing that the circles above don't change size, what do you expect to be true of our curvature function $\kappa(t)$? [[☃ graded-group 1]] If you would like to get some practice with this type of problem, now is the time you should pull out a pencil and paper. We'll go through it together, you and I, but I'll give you the chance to try each step for yourself before the answer is shown. #### Step 1: Compute derivative The first step to finding curvature is to take the derivative of our function, $\begin{align} \quad \vec{\textbf{v}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \cos(t) \\ \sin(t) \\ t/5 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ This will give us a tangent vector to the curve which we can then mold into a unit tangent vector. Compute this derivative. [[☃ explanation 1]] #### Step 2: Normalize the derivative To get a **unit** tangent vector we have to normalize this derivative vector, which is to say, divide it by Its magnitude. What is the magnitude of this derivative? [[☃ explanation 2]] Thankfully this is a constant. Things are a real pain when it's not. Using the previous two answers, what is our unit tangent vector $T(t)$ as a function of time? [[☃ explanation 3]] #### Step 3: Take the derivative of the unit tangent To get curvature, we must find the derivative of this function, with respect to time, then take its magnitude. What is the derivative of $T(t)$ in this case? [[☃ explanation 4]] #### Step 4: Find the magnitude of this value What is the magnitude of this vector? [[☃ explanation 5]] #### Step 5: Divide this value by $||\vec{\textbf{v}}'(t)||$ To go from $\dfrac{dT}{dt}$ to $\dfrac{dT}{ds}$, we must divide this by the magnitude of the derivative of the original parametric function. [[☃ explanation 6]] Notice, this is a constant, so the curvature is the same at all points on the curve. ## Summary - The radius of curvature at a point on a curve is, loosely speaking, the radius of a circle which fits the curve most snugly at that point. - The **curvature**, denoted $\kappa$, is one divided by the radius of curvature. - To find the curvature given the parametric function $\vec{\textbf{s}}$ defining a curve: - Find the unit tangent vector by normalizing the derivative of $\vec{\textbf{s}}$: $\begin{align} \quad T(t) = \dfrac{\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)}{||\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)||} \end{align}$ - Curvature is defined as the magnitude of the derivative of this value with respect to arc length $s$. You can compute that as follows: >> $ \kappa = \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{ds} \right|\right| = \dfrac{ \left|\left| \dfrac{dT}{dt} \right|\right| }{ \left|\left| \dfrac{d\vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt} \right|\right| } $ - The intuition here is that the unit tangent vector tells you which direction you are moving, and the rate at which it changes with respect to small steps $ds$ along the curve is a good indication of how quickly you are turning.

## Background - [Interpreting derivatives of vector valued functions](g/a/derivatives-of-vector-valued-functions) - [Partial derivatives](g/a/introduction-to-partial-derivatives/) - [Parametric surfaces](g/a/parametric-functions-two-parameters/) ## What we're building to - As setup, we have some vector-valued function with a two-dimensional input and a three-dimensional output: > $ \vec{\textbf{v}}(s, t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x(s, t) \\ y(s, t) \\ z(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] $ Its partial derivatives are computed by taking the partial derivative of each component: $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial x}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial x}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ - You can interpret these partial derivatives as giving vectors tangent to the parametric surface defined by $\vec{\textbf{v}}$. ## The goal Suppose I were to give you a function with a two-dimensional input, and a three-dimensional output, like this one: > $ \vec{\textbf{v}}(t, s) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3\cos(t) + \cos(t)\cos(s) \\ 3\sin(t) + \sin(t)\cos(s) \\ \sin(s) \end{array} \right] $ Since the input is multi-dimensional, you cannot take the ordinary derivative of this function, but you can take a partial derivative. The focus of this article is on getting an intuitive feel for what those partial derivatives mean. ## Interpret the function as a surface The function itself actually has a very nice geometric meaning. Since it has a two-coordinate input and a three-coordinate output, we can visualize it as a [parametric surface](g/a/parametric-functions-two-parameters). Specifically, consider all inputs $(t, s)$ such that $0 \le t \le 2\pi$ and $0 \le s \le 2\pi$. This can be seen as a square in the "$ts$-plane". I'll draw this with a checkerboard pattern since it makes things easier to follow later on. [[☃ image 9]] For any given point $(t, s)$, the value $\vec{\textbf{v}}(t, s)$ is some point in three-dimensional space. **Concept check**: Evaluate $\vec{\textbf{v}}(\pi, \pi)$. In other words, where does the function $\vec{\textbf{v}}$ take the input $(t, s) = (\pi, \pi)$? [[☃ explanation 2]] [[☃ graded-group 1]] [[☃ explanation 1]] If you imagine doing this computation for all inputs $(t, s)$ in the square, getting some point in three-dimensional space each time, all of the resulting outputs will form a two-dimensional surface in three-dimensional space. I like to imagine each point of the square moving to its appropriate location in space. [[☃ video 1]] The result is a doughnut shape! Math folk call this a torus. ## Interpreting the partial derivatives #### Differentiate with respect to $\blueE{t}$ To compute a partial derivative of this function, say $\dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial t}$, you take the partial derivative of each individual component. $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial \blueE{t}}(\blueE{t}, s) &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{t}} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3\cos(\blueE{t}) + \cos(\blueE{t})\cos(s) \\ \\ 3\sin(\blueE{t}) + \sin(\blueE{t})\cos(s) \\ \\ \sin(s) \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{t}}(3\cos(\blueE{t}) + \cos(\blueE{t})\cos(s)) \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{t}}(3\sin(\blueE{t}) + \sin(\blueE{t})\cos(s)) \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \blueE{t}}(\sin(s)) \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3\sin(t) - \sin(t)\cos(s) \\ \\ 3\cos(t) + \cos(t)\cos(s) \\ \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \\ \end{align}$ So...what does this new vector-valued function actually mean? Well, computing this partial derivative requires treating the variable $s$ as if it was constant. What does this mean geometrically? In the $ts$-plane, a constant value of $s$ corresponds with a horizontal line. Here's one such line representing $s = \pi/2$, drawn in red: [[☃ image 1]] After this square gets warped and morphed into the torus, this red line gets turned in​to some circle which goes the long way around the torus: [[☃ image 2]] The partial derivative $\dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial t}$ tells us how the output changes slightly when we nudge the input in the $t$-direction. In this case, the vector representing that nudge (drawn in yellow below) gets transformed into a vector tangent to the red circle which represents a constant value of $s$ on the surface: [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] Specifically, the input point used for the pictures above is $(t_0, s_0) = \left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}, \dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)$. This means the point on the torus is $\begin{align} \quad \vec{\textbf{v}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}, \dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3\cos(\pi/4) + \cos(\pi/4)\cos(\pi/2) \\ 3\sin(\pi/4) + \sin(\pi/4)\cos(\pi/2) \\ \sin(\pi/2) \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}(0) \\ 3\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}(0) \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ \\ \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \\ \end{align}$ And the tangent vector is $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial t} \left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}, \dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3\sin(\pi/4) - \sin(\pi/4)\cos(\pi/2) \\ 3\cos(\pi/4) + \cos(\pi/4)\cos(\pi/2) \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}(0) \\ 3\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}(0) \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \\ \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} -\dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \\ \end{align}$ **Concept check**: Why does it make sense that the $z$-component of this tangent vector is $0$? [[☃ graded-group 1]] #### Differentiate with respect to $\redE{s}$ The partial derivative with respect to $s$ is similar. You compute it by taking the partial derivative of each component in the definition of $\vec{\textbf{v}}$: $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial \redE{s}}(t, \redE{s}) = \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \redE{s}} &\left[ \begin{array}{c} 3\cos(t) + \cos(t)\cos(\redE{s}) \\ 3\sin(t) + \sin(t)\cos(\redE{s}) \\ \sin(\redE{s}) \end{array} \right] \\ = &\left[ \begin{array}{c} -\cos(t)\sin(s) \\ -\sin(t)\sin(s) \\ \cos(s) \end{array} \right] \\ \end{align}$ This time, we can imagine holding $t$ constant to get some vertical line in the parameter space. [[☃ image 5]] The yellow arrow represents some velocity vector as a particle travels up along this line. Which is to say, as you vary $s$ while holding $t$ constant. After the square turns into the torus via the function $\vec{\textbf{v}}$, the red line and the yellow velocity vector might look something like this: [[☃ image 6]] The partial derivative $\dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\partial s}$ can be interpreted as this resulting velocity vector on the torus. ## Summary - As setup, we have some vector-valued function with a two-dimensional input and a three-dimensional output: > $ \vec{\textbf{v}}(s, t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x(s, t) \\ y(s, t) \\ z(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] $ Its partial derivatives are computed by taking the partial derivative of each component: $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial x}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\blueE{\partial t}}(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ $\begin{align} \quad \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{\partial x}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\redE{\partial s}}(s, t) \\ \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ - You can interpret these partial derivatives as giving vectors tangent to the parametric surface defined by $\vec{\textbf{v}}$. - For example, imagine nudging a point in the input space along the $\blueE{t}$ direction, say from the coordinates $(s, t)$ to the coordinates $(s, t+\redE{h})$ for some small $\redE{h}$. This results in some small nudge in the output along the surface, which is represented by the vector $\redE{h} \dfrac{\partial \vec{\textbf{v}}}{{\partial t}}(s, t)$.

## Background - [Ordinary derivatives](/a/differentiation-rules-review) - [Parametric function](/a/parametric-functions) ## What we're building to - To take the derivative of a vector-valued function, take the derivative of each component: $\begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dt} \left[ \begin{array}{c} x(t) \\\\ y(t) \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x'(t) \\\\ y'(t) \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ - If you interpret the initial function as giving the position of a particle as a function of time, the derivative gives the velocity vector of that particle as a function of time. [[☃ image 1]] ## The derivative of a vector-valued function Good news! Computing the derivative of a vector-valued​ function is nothing really new. As such, I'll keep this article pretty short. The main new takeaway is interpreting the vector derivative. ## Dive in with an example Let's start with a relatively simple vector-valued function $\vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$, with only two components, $\begin{align} \vec{\textbf{s}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \sin(t) \\\\ 2 \cos(t/3)t \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ To take the derivative of $\vec{\textbf{s}}$, just take the derivative of each component: $ \begin{align} \dfrac{d \vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt}(t) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} \dfrac{d}{dt}(2 \sin(t)) \\\\ \dfrac{d}{dt}(2 \cos(t/3))t \end{array} \right] \\\\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2\cos(t) \\\\ 2 \cos(t/3) - \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(t/3)t \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ You might also write this derivative as $\vec{\textbf{s}}'(t)$. This derivative is a new vector-valued function, with the same input $t$ that $\vec{\textbf{s}}$ has, and whose output has the same number of dimensions. More generally, if we write the components of $\vec{\textbf{s}}$ as $x(t)$ and $y(t)$, we write its derivative like this: $\begin{align} \vec{\textbf{s}}'(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x'(t) \\\\ y'(t) \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ ## Derivative gives a velocity vector. For the example above, how can we visualize what the derivative means? First, to visualize $\begin{align} \vec{\textbf{s}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \sin(t) \\\\ 2 \cos(t/3)t \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ we note that the output has more dimensions than the input, so it is well-suited to be viewed as a [parametric function](/a/parametric-functions). Each point on the curve represents the tip of a vector $ \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \sin(t_0) \\ 2 \cos(t_0/3)t_0 \end{array} \right]$ for some specific number $t_0$. For instance, when $t_0=2$ we draw a vector to the point $\begin{align} \vec{\textbf{s}}(2) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \sin(2) \\\\ 2 \cos(2/3)\cdot 2 \end{array} \right] \approx \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1.819 \\\\ 3.144 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ [[☃ image 1]] When we do this for all possible inputs $t$, the tips of the vectors $\vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$ will trace out a certain curve: [[☃ image 4]] What do we get when we plug in some value of $t$, perhaps $2$ again, to the derivative? $ \begin{align} \dfrac{d \vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt}(2) &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2\cos(2) \\\\ 2 \cos(2/3) - \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2/3)\cdot 2 \end{array} \right]\\\\ &\approx \left[ \begin{array}{c} -0.832 \\\\ 0.747 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ This is also some two-dimensional vector. [[☃ image 5]] It's hard to see what this derivative vector represents when it just sits at the origin, but if we shift it so that its tail sits on the tip of the vector $\vec{\textbf{s}}(2)$, it has a wonderful interpretation: - **If $ \vec{\textbf{s}}(t)$ represents the position of a traveling particle as a function of time, $\dfrac{d \vec{\textbf{s}}}{dt}(t_0)$ is the velocity vector of that particle at time $t_0$.** [[☃ image 5]] In particular, this means the direction of the vector is tangent to the curve, and its magnitude indicates the speed at which one travels along this curve as $t$ increases at a constant rate (as time tends to do). **Concept Check**: Suppose the position in two-dimensional space of a particle, as a function of time, is given by the function $\begin{align} \vec{\textbf{s}}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} t^2 \\\\ t^3 \end{array} \right] \end{align}$ [[☃ graded-group 2]] [[☃ graded-group 1]] ## Summary - To take the derivative of a vector-valued function, take the derivative of each component. - If you interpret the initial function as giving the position of a particle as a function of time, the derivative gives the velocity vector of that particle as a function of time.
